replies.commentBody: For men like Trump, there is never "enough" that is how they get to where they are. They are never satisfied. That is the fundamental characteristic many people miss about his kind.

comments.commentBody: I think Trump has accumulated enough fame, fortune, power, etc. that he is not interested in garnering more through his position as president. On the contrary, those are what got him to be the president. I think he now wants the challenge of running a country, testing his intelligence and knowledge against the impossible task of making the country prosperous, safe,, and respected abroad. I think that his ego and narcissism and desire to be "the best ever" would preclude his using his power for mere business success. Once you have enough material stuff, it's enough. I voted third party, not for Trump. Still, I think he is motivated by his sense of anger at government that has been corrupt and stupid and his sense that he can fix it.

When I was a New York State employee, I had to have permission to work a small part-time job. I actually had to have it approved by the ethics division. If they had disapproved my receiving a small amount of pay for this job, I offered to volunteer to do the job. They said that if I had been turned down to do the job, they could also turn me down to volunteer for the job. My NYS job was not and elected position; my outside job, which is six to seven hours per week, provides no conflict of interest at all. I have since retired from my NYS job and just do the small PT job.

And, just like every other person at my level, I had to file an extensive annual financial disclosure.

I was not the governor or a cabinet secretary, and yet, I was under that kind of scrutiny. But the chief executive of the entire United States does not have to report his potential conflicts of interest? My financial dealings pale by comparison; yet he is immune? He claims to care about the average American. What would he even know about what day-to-day issues the average American faces, vis-a-vis ethics? The people who voted for him are so uninformed about what even a conflict of interest is, and they seem to care even less. They have been conned by the epitome of a Barnum and Bailey sleight-of-hand Ponzzi schemer. The country will suffer immeasurably because of their nonchalance about these issues. Trump's lying hypocrisy and his liaison with Russia is incomprehensible to me.

There are likely hundreds of conflicts-of-interests associated with the many Trump business entities. What's most concerning is potential violations of the Emoluments Clause of the Constitution which prohibits the President from receiving "gifts" from foreign states.

I've learned many things about our government since the current President-elect won.  The most significant was that there is no provision for overseeing that the U.S. President is clear of any conflict of interest (or that s/he show the American people their tax returns).  Who will keep tabs on this?  Whose responsibility is it?  My predominant concern though is that those who were desperate enough to vote for Trump won't care when blatant conflict of interests occur if they get a job out of the deal.  So here's the question: How much of our American democratic values are we willing to sacrifice for jobs?

Trump's hypocrisy is endless.  During the election he criticized Hillary Clinton's ethics in relation to the Clinton Foundation and buying exposure to the Secretary, but her involvement paled in comparison to the conflicts of Trump and his children with their business and their roles in government.  Before he was inaugurated, his sons tried hatching a scheme to reap millions of dollars for an opportunity to meet with the elder Trump after the inauguration, sullying the gravity and pomp of what is usually a solemn and important event for our nation.   Trump believes that he not obligated to divest himself of his business concerns and it is doubtful that he will.  He is in a perfect position to use the power of the office to assist his company in reaping countless benefits, with no one that will stop him.  The idea that Mitch McConnell would actually confront him about the blatant conflicts of interest is laughable.  McConnell has made it clear that he values his power over the country's best interests.  Likewise, Trump will place his company's bottom line before the interests of the majority of Americans.   That so many voters believed that he was the best choice to lead our country continues to puzzle and horrify me.  That so many view Putin in a positive light is equally as frightening.

Trump's conflicts of interest are troubling not merely because of his likely self aggrandizement. If unchecked they will flout vital standards for future presidents and diminish the presidency and the nation.

replies.commentBody: Sorry, they are their own lobbyists.

comments.commentBody: Millionaires and billionaires can easily fend off lobbyists. Perhaps that is the best definition for "draining the swamp."

Trump's DNA is how to work the system i.e. Taxes, highly leveraged financing and making money on others finances. Plus, he has a lot of international loans. He does not have the morality to leave all of that behind. We will be at the mercy of his ethics. Then there is the issue of what a democracy expects from government. Like infrastructure, services and order. This administration will do a lot to privatize these services which will decrease value to citizens in the form of higher costs. I am a retired physician and I know first hand for profit healthcare and how it has affected access and quality. Billionaires will want to continue profitizing and that is a huge conflict of interest. I believe we are no longer a democracy bot an oligarchy. These men will worsen that because of their mind set.

It isn't only Trump who will have conflicts of interest; it is many of his picks for the cabinet.

He has indeed transferred many predators from their normal places in society into the heart of our republic.

One can only hope that there are enough honest Republicans left in the House and the Senate to see treason when it occurs.

replies.commentBody: Your presuming the public is informed and understands how our government works.  Were that true, Hillary Clinton would be the President - elect.
Well, she did get almost 3 million more votes

I think he was also closing his foundation to shut down NYS investigation into it's many improprieties, and hope he was unpleasantly surprised when they wouldn't let him shut it down while the investigation is on-going. A prologue of what's to come.

comments.commentBody: Trump underestimates much but this much is absolute, that we the people believe anything he says.  He stupidly thinks we don't know why he is shedding his foundation.  A foundation that no longer has any employees, or funds...to steal for his own use.  To quit his foundation is the same kind of ploy he has used against the gullible people that voted for him.  To say he gave up the foundation gives him, so he thinks, a credibility that he cares about "conflicts of interest," except there is no content to the foundation so giving it up is like giving up nothing! But the perception, so he thinks, is that he at least has given up something!  What a hilarity!  The news media keeps muttering "at least it is a step in the right direction," is another belly laugh, as it is a step all right, but since there is no content, the news reports, as usual, are just as empty!  For him to impress the public, he has to give up his involvements in all of his "investments" to be President.  But we know he won't be doing that, and it is only a symptom he demonstrates that he is not fit to be President!  Furthermore, he hasn't had news conferences for six months because he knows he will be asked about his taxes and his lies about making donations to charities and using charity funds for his own edification!  He is evading the truth, as the news media will not let up on requiring him to tell it!

I do not think the government should be responsible for protecting buildings around the world with the Trump name on them---that is his responsibility. My concern--facetious as it may seem, but in keeping with his ego-- is he may want to rename the government buildings: Trump Treasury, Trump FBI,  Trump Post Office, Trump Dept. of Health and Human Services--probably the most ironic since narcissists typically have no empathy for anyone else.

There's no question that Trump will become president with all kinds of conflicts of interest problems, but my concern is about Congress. Will they rise to the occasion when the constitution is being violated. Most of these politicians have become wealthy while in Congress and therefore would like to keep the gravy train going. So, forget about the high-minded talk from only a few of the media, and accept what you have made possible.

replies.commentBody: Or that foreign nations hacking us, ergo our national safety, is worthy of investigating and is rather something we should "move on" from!!

comments.commentBody: I really think there are more problems with Donald Trump's decision making than possible conflicts of interest. This just isn't a big problem compared to the fact he just doesn't that using nuclear weapons is mass murder, for example.

Given trump's organizations world-wide reach and his refusal to divulge tax information he is literally asking the Amercan Electorate to "Trust Him".  Given what is known about trumps dealings e.g. his university,  his "charitable organization, etc.  that's the last thing that we should do.    From all I have read about the president elect trump has only one loyalty himself.  the potential for his conflicts of interest and his office doing significant damage to this nation is immense and frightening.  Our only hope is that the Times & the free press will thoroughly investigate track & report to the public on its findings.   As Jefferson so succinctly put it -  “Our liberty depends on the freedom of the press, and that cannot be limited without being lost.”
I am MORE concerned about the seemingly non-existent desire to hold the president accountable for such conflict of interests.

Much has been written about the president elect's possible conflicts and there are, for sure, many to be raised. While domestic and foreign decisions may be affected by the many ramifications of the Trump family business (as they already seem to be, even before Mr. trump actually takes office), the one area that appears to be overlooked in many cases is how the situation may affect national security during the course of his coming administration should Mr. trump not divest his business and put the proceeds in a true blind trust. The question that comes to mind is, when (not whether) a Trump business interest on foreign soil becomes the strategic target of foreign military, militia or terrorist activities, will this constitute an act of war against the U.S.? Will an attack against a Trump hotel become a proxy attack against our national interest and call for a military response on our part?
We should all be highly concerned about the conflicts surrounding decisions that will be made in the name of this country that could have for object the protection or furthering of the president-elect's interests, both foreign and domestic. We should equally raise the question of whether we want to put the sons and daughters of this country in harms way to protect his property because he would not part with them. The last time this country was asked to answer this call, royalty was the authority over this land.

replies.commentBody:
Surely you know his adoring fans gave him the pet name "blue-collar" billionaire. That makes him different from that know-it-all elite millionaire Hillary Clinton.
Well, we all know he loves the poorly educated!

comments.commentBody: I am afraid we will see an extreme version of "to the unexpected victor belongs the spoils." It used to be that the ultra-rich influenced government with their money-well , of course, they still do and will--but this Trump win means that the ultra rich are now actually the government, what with Trump as president and crony billionaires as cabinet ministers. It is curious that Hillary Clinton was rejected because she was seen as favoring the elite, and the country elected a billionaire as president. Ethics and legalities have been trumped by the blind anger in parts of the country which wanted to send a message.

Conflict of interest extends beyond the trump family's purely financial matters.

World wide, US assets like marine barracks and naval vessels have been considered vulnerable to terrorist attacks and have accordingly been increasingly protected. When trump takes office, the trump name attached to many structures around the world will greatly increase the number of potential targets. Who will be responsible for their protection? The US Marines? The host nations' police and/or military? At whose expense? How would US policy towards those nations be influenced? How do you give hotel or apartment buildings, which depend on the free access of their residents, the same level of security as an embassy or military base?

Such conflicts of interest may have already passed the point of no return. The trumps may remove the family name from the buildings and sever all financial interest in them, but the association will always remain in the minds of people who want to do harm.

Besides, with the trump habit of secrecy and lying, how can anyone - friend or foe - believe that any announced divestiture would be complete and final? I can just see trump announcing full divestiture and the gullible media swallowing it as he says "believe me" while transferring the family assets to a bunch of untraceable shell corporations.

The conflicts of interest are real - and if any of his family have a role in the government they too will have conflicts of interest. On day one citizens should press for impeachment hearings to begin based on the various illegalities these continued business connections will have. Monitor it closely, very closely and the legitimate press must press with investigative journalism day after day after day. This means also fighting to make sure Sessions is NOT confirmed as AG and Tillerson ( who it appears will also have serious conflicts of interest) is NOT confirmed as Secretary of State.

At 12:01 p.m. on Jan. 20th, 2017, all the Democratic Representatives and Senators, the ACLU, and top Constitutional scholars should join together to petition the House to investigate the potentially thousands of violations of the Constitution's Emoluments Clause created by Trump's apparent conflicts of interest, income, gifts, subsidies, and contracts, and all other forms of emoluments and profits involving foreign governments and those businesses, including banks, controlled or guided by such governments. That should lead to the House recommending Articles of Impeachment. You say it can never happen in a Congress controlled by Republicans? Remember how nearly all Democrats assumed Trump could never win the election? And the GOP Congress can still end up naming another (somewhat more normal) fellow Republican as President.

If the shoe were on the other foot, the counterattack would be well under way, and dominating news cycles.  Inauguration day would commence a feeding frenzy that would not cease til they got their way. Hell or high water, by any means necessary.  We have (crickets chirping) because Democrats are cravenly triangulating instead, and god forbid they should offend a racist.  Of course it would not be possible for anything like this to happen the other way 'round, but that's a whole other topic.

Editors, this is a poorly conceived poll. If 96% of the respondents agree, then you've not shaped the question the right way! Give us questions that will create insightful results.
I hope a never see this type of factoid used in your reporting even though it's statistically okay : "In a recent poll 96% of Americans expressed concern about ..."

It is not possible to determine whether the man is receiving "emoluments" or not unless you know his business.

It follows that he has a duty to set out all his business and financial interests before congress.

replies.commentBody: You should be concerned. He is in  it for the money and recognition.

When was America "not great?" How can you make something "great again" if it's always been great? You can improve something, but make it great "again?" What he wants to do is make it "white again," i.e., bring us back to the 1950s, where women and minorities knew their place, where white men reigned supreme, and where the whole "Mad Men" mentality ruled the country. Since I lived through those times, I'm not going back. And since you're in China--what's your beef?
He will certainly make himself greater, before he makes this country greater. Narcissism is it's own reward.

comments.commentBody: I'm not concerned at all about Trump's conflicts, if he makes America great again.

replies.commentBody: I believe you mean that Trump COULDN'T care less.

comments.commentBody: We care, yes, but Trump could care less
